div.p: REGION, a globally available sub-element of PLACE, captures the name of the place only and excludes all punctuation. It must be followed by a GEOG tag (except in cases where a REGION straddles more than one GEOG), and has optional attributes CURRENT and REG. It captures the following geographical and political units:

ul.li: Political regions (counties) of the British Isles: Cornwall, Durham, Hampshire
Political regions (provinces or states) of other countries: Alberta, Madras, California
Topographical features: all mountain ranges, individual mountains, islands (when not nation states), valleys, forests, etc.
Bodies of Water (including oceans, rivers, lakes): Lake Simcoe, English Channel, Nile, Atlantic Ocean.
Geographical regions: Lake District, Scottish Highlands, Welsh border, Tibetan border.

div.p: See PLACE for general practice issues.

For all settlements in the British Isles, Canada, the US, and Australia a REGION and a GEOG sub-element must be included. If you do not want to include the name of the region/geog in your prose, use an empty tag with text in the REG attribute only.

div.u: Standard Vocabulary for Regions of the British Isles
div.p: The following is a list of regions (counties) that the Orlando Project uses to standardize regions in the British Isles. All places within the British Isles require one of these names. For specific practice issues around the use of these regions, see Practice Issues discussions which follow these lists. The abbreviations may be found in your source, but Orlando does not use them.
England:

ul.li: Avon (county taking in Bristol and Bath, which lasted only 1974-98)
Cumberland (now abolished, amalgamated with Westmorland as Cumbria)
Devon (do not use Devonshire, Dorsetshire, or Somersetshire, tho they may be found in source).
Herefordshire (recently amalgamated with its neighbour to form Hereford and Worcester: during 1974-98)
Merseyside (recently created; used to be partly Lancs, partly Cheshire)
Rutland (used to be smallest county: gone)
Sussex (now administratively divided into West and East)
Tyne and Wear (recently created from partly Durham, partly Northumberland)
West Midlands (recent creation; do not know why they didn't call it Greater Birmingham on analogy with London/ Manchester)
Yorkshire (Yorks: now divided administratively into North, West, and South Yorks, though historical division was into Ridings: North, West, and East)

div.p: [In general use historic county names, with explanatory SCHOLARNOTE as necessary. A SCHOLARNOTE is welcome, too, in cases of boundary change. Do not say Somersetshire, Devonshire, or Dorsetshire.]
Wales:

ul.li: Clwyd (used to be Denbigh and Flint)
Dyfed (used to be Cardigan, Carmarthen, and Pembroke)
Glamorgan (Glam: the industrial part, name amazingly survived; now divided into West Glam, Mid Glam and South Glam)
Gwynedd (used to be Caernarvon, Merioneth, and the separate island of Anglesey)
Powys (used to be Montgomery, Radnor, and Brecknock)

div.p: [Note: The old Welsh county names often come with -shire attached, but it's not correct. Unlike practice with English names, use current names when possible, as courtesy to the Welsh language. Fill in REG tag with traditional (English) name if it’s in your source, and repeat present-day name in CURRENT attribute so that both come up in search results.]
Scotland:

ul.li: Borders (a new entity swallowing up Berwick, Peebles, Roxburgh, Selkirk)
Central (used to be Clackmannan, Stirling, and part of Perth)
Clackmannan (smallest Scots county, now in Central)
Dumfries and Galloway (new entity, taking in Dumfries, Kirkcudbright, and Wigtown)
Fife (used to be Kinross and Fife)
Grampian (used to be Aberdeen, Banff, Kincardine, Moray)
Highland (used to be Caithness, Inverness, Nairn, Ross and Cromarty - a doublet - and Sutherland)
Inner Hebrides (now divided between Highland and Strathclyde)
Kirkcudbright, pronounced Kircoobry (now part of Dumfries and Galloway)
Lothian (used to be West Lothian, Midlothian, East Lothian)
Orkney (separate group of islands, administratively a county of Scotland)
Outer Hebrides (now officially known by traditional name of Western Isles)
Shetland (separate group of islands, administratively a county of Scotland)
Strathclyde (used to be Argyll, Ayr, Bute, Dunbarton, Lanark, Renfrew)
Tayside (used to be Angus, Kinross, Perth)
Wigtown (now part of Dumfries and Galloway)

div.p: [Note: Most Scottish county names do not use shire.]
Other Scottish area names which are old but may still be used:

Orlando practice is much less clear over Scotland than over England or Wales. Hebrides has been used as a REGION, which is accurate geographically if not administratively. It seems a shame for ancient names like Badenoch and Braemar to vanish into composite bureaucratic abstractions. We are still using Midlothian as the REGION for Edinburgh. Just follow your source; try to use the attributes CURRENT and REG helpfully for users; remember if you use one of these you need to use both to keep both in play.
Ireland:

Older sources often give County Mayo, County Clare, etc. (for some English counties too). If you follow this, use REG attribute value without the County. Of ancient Irish kingdoms: Connaught or Connacht included: Mayo, Roscommon, Galway; Munster included Limerick, Kerry, Cork, part of Tipperary. Connacht and Munster can be used as REGIONs too.
Northern Ireland:

Do NOT abbreviate names of regions: not Glos but Gloucestershire. The abbreviated names provided above are simply to identify short forms used in other reference sources. If you do not wish to spell out the region in prose, do so in a REG attribute.
Do NOT use co for counties even if your source does (i.e. use Durham and not Co. Durham).

For all places in Northern Ireland, include one of the six counties. Irish placenames pose some particular problems because of the changing political constitution of the region. For example, Belfast. By making sure to include a region sub-element for all places in Northern Ireland, we can geographically locate the places rather than entering into the politically fractious debate about Ireland vs. Northern Ireland and the histories thereof. Only the GEOG changes for the Six Counties, from being part of Ireland to becoming part of Northern Ireland: in these cases use CURRENT attribute on the Geog.
Islands are regions except when they are nation states. For example, Crete is a REGION with a GEOG sub-element for Greece, whereas Barbados (topographically an island) is a GEOG.
Standard way of referring to Isle of Skye is Isle of Skye and not just Skye.

Mountain Ranges: try to include a GEOG element when one country embraces the range, and use the formal title (e.g. Rocky Mountains not Rockies). Do not include the in the REGION sub-element. If you don’t know which GEOG is meant, omit this tag.
Topographical regions: here are some standard allowable topographical REGIONs:

ul.li: Brecon Beacons: Brecknock (don't confuse w next)
Cheviot Hills (Northumberland and Roxburgh [now Borders], Scotland)
Home Counties: originally Kent, Surrey, Essex, Middlesex; later incl Bucks, Berks, Herts and Sussex (source, Brewer).
The Lake District: Cumberland and Westmorland
North Downs: in Kent and Surrey
South Downs: in Kent and Sussex
Thames Valley: Surrey, Berks, Bucks, Oxon

div.p: [Note: Remember, articles are not placed inside sub-elements]

Valleys can be tagged as REGIONs; try to include an identifiable GEOG. Bodies of waters are REGIONs but, wherever possible, situate them within a regularized attribute of an identifiable GEOG or other REGION. Include the name of the type of body of water within the prose (for example, river, lake, ocean).
<PLACE>the <REGION>River Nile<REGION/><GEOG REG="Egypt"></GEOG> but <PLACE><REGION>River Danube</REGION></PLACE> [since it flows through more than one GEOG].
When a place was formerly a geo-political entity but is now a Region within a country, or vice versa (for example, Upper Canada or Newfoundland) make use of the Current attribute:
When a border is tagged, the term "border" must be included in the prose of the Region sub-element: <REGION>Welsh Borders</REGION><GEOG REG=”Wales”></GEOG>
Question: Are the Balkan Countries a region?
Answer: No. They're a GEOG. Regions apply only to areas which are conceptually smaller than nation states. If the place is a collection of nation states, enter as a GEOG.
